questions.text: A 29-year-old woman had an IUD inserted at a PHC. After a few months, she conceives. On examination, the IUD is still in place. She wants to continue with her pregnancy. Next best step of management is? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Remove IUD gently, then do MTP

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Remove IUD gently

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If a woman conceives with an IUD in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUD should be gently removed to minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to a clinic in a developing region after receiving the MMR vaccination as part of a mass immunization program. Supplemental vitamin A is given alongside the vaccination. What is the appropriate dose of vitamin A to be given immediately after the MMR vaccination and then on the following day? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 1,00,000 IU

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For children aged 6-12 months, the appropriate dose of vitamin A supplementation given alongside the MMR vaccine is 1,00,000 IU.

questions.text: A case of trauma presents to the Emergency with an unknown blood group. Since the patient was hemodynamically unstable, he required immediate blood transfusion. Which blood type can be transfused? ( INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. O positive and O negative
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) O positive and O negative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Universal blood donor and the safest option: O negative.

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Recommended dietary allowance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)
  • ➤ Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)
  • ➤ Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable. For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.
  • ➤ Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • ➤ RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • ➤ RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • ➤ RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • ➤ RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • ➤ RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • ➤ For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

questions.text: You're rotating in the infection control unit of a tertiary care hospital in Chennai. As part of your duties, you have been assigned to educate the staff about the importance of precautionary measures and isolation techniques for various conditions. While discussing droplet precautions, one of the staff inquired about the diseases for which such precautions are necessary. Which of the following conditions does NOT typically require precautionary measures and isolation due to droplet infection? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Localized varicella zoster

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Localized varicella zoster does not require droplet precautions as it is transmitted through direct contact, while conditions like pertussis, diphtheria, and mycoplasma pneumonia require droplet precautions due to their transmission via respiratory droplets.
  • ➤ Localized varicella zoster does not require droplet precautions as it is transmitted through direct contact, while conditions like pertussis, diphtheria, and mycoplasma pneumonia require droplet precautions due to their transmission via respiratory droplets.

questions.text: What is the term for the likelihood that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Positive predictive value (PPV) is the measure that indicates the likelihood that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question. It is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of a screening test in correctly identifying true positive cases.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is admitted with dengue hemorrhagic fever. After several days of management, her condition stabilizes, and the medical team considers discharging her. Which of the following is an appropriate criterion to decide the discharge of a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.correct_answer: B. After the return of appetite
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) After the return of appetite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CRITERIA FOR DISCHARGING PATIENTS:
  • ➤ CRITERIA FOR DISCHARGING PATIENTS:
  • ➤ Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of anti-fever therapy Return of appetite Visible clinical improvement Good urine output Minimum of three days after recovery from shock No respiratory distress from pleural effusion and no ascites Platelet count of more than 50,000/mm
  • ➤ Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of anti-fever therapy
  • ➤ Return of appetite
  • ➤ Visible clinical improvement
  • ➤ Good urine output
  • ➤ Minimum of three days after recovery from shock
  • ➤ No respiratory distress from pleural effusion and no ascites
  • ➤ Platelet count of more than 50,000/mm

questions.text: In a community, there were 550 births in a year out of which 50 were stillbirths. There were 09 deaths among newborns during 0-7 days of life. An additional 41 deaths occurred during 8-28 days of life. Calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality rate for the given community. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 18

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is calculated as the number of early neonatal deaths (0-7 days) per 1,000 live births.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a study that is longitudinal, observational, and includes the analysis of variables to determine associations? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cohort study

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct term for a longitudinal, observational study that involves the analysis of variables to determine associations among a group of people is a "cohort study”.
  • • In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to see how different exposures affect their chances of developing an outcome. It's useful for studying the effects of suspected risk factors that cannot be controlled experimentally.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Case-Control Study : This type of study involves identifying participants based on the presence (case) or absence (control) of a particular outcome or disease and then looking back retrospectively to compare exposure to a risk factor or intervention between the groups.
  • • Option A. Case-Control Study
  • • Option C. Ecological Study : These studies assess risk factors or outcomes in a population based on data at the group level, rather than individual data. It's useful for initial, broad correlations between environmental or contextual factors and health outcomes.
  • • Option C. Ecological Study
  • • Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) : This is an experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to either the group receiving the intervention or to a control group that does not, to compare outcomes in a controlled way.
  • • Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For analyzing how various factors might affect health outcomes over time within a specified group, a cohort study is typically the most appropriate method due to its ability to follow participants through time and observe changes and outcomes as they occur naturally.

questions.text: Which virus outbreak occurred in Kerala following consumption of date palm sap? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nipah virus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala was linked to the consumption of fruits contaminated with bat secretions. Date palm sap, which is a popular drink in the region, can become contaminated with bat secretions containing the Nipah virus when bats feed on the sap. Consumption of this contaminated sap led to the Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ebola virus transmission occurs through contact with contaminated body fluids from infected individuals. It is not associated with the consumption of date palm sap or fruits.
  • • Option
  • • B. Ebola virus
  • • contaminated body fluids
  • • Option C. Litchi Virus Disease, also known as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES), has been reported in West Bengal. It is linked to the consumption of litchis on an empty stomach by children, which can lead to severe hypoglycemia and death due to the generation of methylenecyclopropylglycine (MCPG).
  • • Option
  • • C. Litchi Virus Disease,
  • • empty stomach by children,
  • • severe hypoglycemia and death
  • • Option D. West Nile Fever, transmitted by the Culex pipiens mosquito, has been reported in Kerala.
  • • Option
  • • D. West Nile Fever,
  • • Note - Although a single case of Ebola virus was reported at the Delhi International Airport, it is not related to the Kerala outbreak caused by the consumption of date palm sap.
  • • Note

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala was linked to the consumption of date palm sap contaminated with bat secretions containing the virus.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man visits your clinic with his 2-year-old son, expressing concerns about vaccinations due to a belief in his community that vaccinations can lead to impotency. He is fearful for his son's future but is also influenced by societal beliefs. Addressing his concerns requires overcoming which type of barrier? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cultural barrier

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cultural beliefs can significantly influence health decisions, and understanding these beliefs is crucial for effective healthcare communication and intervention.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to a health clinic with difficulty seeing in the evening and dry, irritated eyes. Her diet mainly consists of rice and lentils, with limited access to green leafy vegetables or animal products. On examination, dryness and Bitot's spots are noted on the conjunctiva. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for her symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Vitamin A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin A deficiency leads to Xerophthalmia, which presents with symptoms like dryness of eyes, night blindness, and Bitot's spots. This condition is common in children with diets lacking in vitamin A-rich foods.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of persistent fatigue. The physician is concerned about a particular condition and orders an on-site diagnostic test to evaluate further. The test, known to have a sensitivity of 98%, returns a negative result. Based on the high sensitivity, what is the most likely implication of this negative test outcome for the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: The patient should undergo another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition.

options.label: B
options.text: There is a 2% prevalence of the disease in the population.

options.label: C
options.text: It is less likely that the patient has the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient has been mistakenly ruled out due to a false negative result.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is less likely that the patient has the disease.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is less likely that the patient has the disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative result in a highly sensitive test (98% sensitivity) makes it very unlikely that the patient has the disease, as false negatives are rare with such tests.
  • ➤ A negative result in a highly sensitive test (98% sensitivity) makes it very unlikely that the patient has the disease, as false negatives are rare with such tests.

options.label: B
options.text: Evident positive skewness, normal distribution, negative skewness, outliers present

options.label: C
options.text: Typical distribution, outliers present, skewed negatively, skewed positively

options.label: D
options.text: Standard distribution, outliers present, evident positive skewness, negative skewness

  • ➤ Description: A convenient way of graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles

  • ➤ Outlier: A data point that is located outside the whiskers of the box plot

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 50

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: During your clinical rotation in infectious diseases, a patient with dengue fever develops warning signs like abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, clinical fluid accumulation, and an increase in hematocrit with a decrease in platelet count. Which of the following is the cornerstone of management for a patient showing warning signs of dengue? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IV Fluids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following are the phases of: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Demographic process

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Demography is the scientific study of human populations, and demographic processes are the key factors that influence population dynamics. The five main demographic processes mentioned in the image are:
  • • Fertility : Related to childbirth and reproduction Mortality : Related to deaths and life expectancy Marriage : Formation and dissolution of marital unions Migration : Physical or geographical movement of people from one place to another Social mobility : Movement of individuals across social classes or socio-economic status
  • • Fertility : Related to childbirth and reproduction
  • • Fertility
  • • Mortality : Related to deaths and life expectancy
  • • Mortality
  • • Marriage : Formation and dissolution of marital unions
  • • Marriage
  • • Migration : Physical or geographical movement of people from one place to another
  • • Migration
  • • Social mobility : Movement of individuals across social classes or socio-economic status
  • • Social mobility
  • • These processes collectively determine the size, structure, and distribution of populations over time.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Demographic dividend : This refers to the economic growth potential resulting from a population's changing age structure, typically when the working-age population is larger than the non-working-age population. It is not directly related to the five processes listed.
  • • Option
  • • B. Demographic dividend
  • • Option C. Demographic cycle: Also known as the demographic transition model, this describes the stages a population goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. While related to demographic processes, the stages of the demographic cycle are not the same as the processes listed.
  • • Option
  • • C. Demographic cycle:
  • • Option D. Human Development Index (HDI): This is a composite statistic developed by the United Nations to measure and rank countries' levels of social and economic development. It takes into account life expectancy, education, and per capita income. HDI is not directly related to the five demographic processes mentioned.
  • • Option
  • • D. Human Development Index (HDI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fertility, mortality, marriage, migration, and social mobility are the five main demographic processes that influence population dynamics and are studied in the field of demography.

questions.text: Which of the following calculates one variable using another variable? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The Coefficient of Regression is used to calculate or predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable, quantifying the relationship between the independent and dependent variables in regression analysis.

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

  • ➤ isolate affected individuals for 6 days

  • ➤ Randomisation (2nd Best Method)
  • ➤ (2nd Best Method)
  • ➤ Restriction
  • ➤ Stratification
  • ➤ Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)
  • ➤ Stratified Randomization (Overall Best Method)

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the point from A to C in the given flowchart depicting the natural history of a disease? (NEET PG 2019)

  • ➤ Lead time is the interval between the detection of a disease through screening and its usual time of diagnosis due to symptom presentation.

  • ➤ Early detection of disease due to screening (B rather than C) will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

questions.text: The table provided illustrates a multivariate analysis assessing the relationship between the risk of blindness and various factors including age, literacy rate, place of residence, and gender. Which of the subsequent statements accurately interprets this data? (INICET MAY 2022) Female population is at greater risk of developing blindness. People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness. Risk of developing blindness increases with age. Illiteracy leads to increased risk of developing blindness.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Odds ratio interpretation:
  • ➤ Odds ratio interpretation:
  • ➤ Odds ratio of 1: Indicates that the risk factor is not related to the disease. Odds ratio less than 1: Indicates that a person with the disease is less likely to have been exposed to the factor, implying that the factor may be protective. Odds ratio greater than 1: Indicates that the factor is associated with an increased risk of the disease.
  • ➤ Odds ratio of 1: Indicates that the risk factor is not related to the disease.
  • ➤ Odds ratio of 1:
  • ➤ Odds ratio less than 1: Indicates that a person with the disease is less likely to have been exposed to the factor, implying that the factor may be protective.
  • ➤ Odds ratio less than 1:
  • ➤ Odds ratio greater than 1: Indicates that the factor is associated with an increased risk of the disease.
  • ➤ Odds ratio greater than 1:
  • ➤ p-value interpretation:
  • ➤ p-value interpretation:
  • ➤ p-value < 0.05: Indicates that the result is statistically significant. p-value > 0.05: Indicates that the result is not statistically significant.
  • ➤ p-value < 0.05: Indicates that the result is statistically significant.
  • ➤ p-value < 0.05:
  • ➤ p-value > 0.05: Indicates that the result is not statistically significant.
  • ➤ p-value > 0.05:

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to an antenatal clinic at PHC and gives a history of Diabetes in her mother. Diabetic screening is carried out for this pregnant woman at
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 24-28 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diabetic screening in pregnant women, especially those with a family history of diabetes, is typically performed between 24 to 28 weeks of gestation. This period is chosen because it is when insulin resistance usually begins to increase due to hormonal changes in pregnancy. The screening is done using the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) to confirm gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diabetic screening for pregnant women is best performed between 24-28 weeks of gestation using the oral glucose tolerance test to diagnose gestational diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Primary health center

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are responsible for managing school health programs in India, providing a range of health services to ensure the well-being of school children.

questions.explanation:

questions.text: Imagine a scenario where a novel medication is introduced that significantly reduces mortality from a specific disease but does not actually cure the disease. As patients continue to live longer with the disease due to this medication, it would have an effect on the epidemiological metrics. Which of the following statements correctly describes the expected change in prevalence and incidence as a result of this medication? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increase in prevalence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PREVALENCE
  • ➤ PREVALENCE
  • ➤ Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over. Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d] Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery
  • ➤ Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • ➤ Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • ➤ Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery
  • ➤ INCIDENCE
  • ➤ INCIDENCE
  • ➤ Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.
  • ➤ Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

questions.text: A recent medical graduate is attending a seminar on Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM). The speaker emphasizes EBM's integrative approach to patient care. Which statement most accurately encapsulates the core philosophy of EBM? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: EBM mandates that clinical decisions should exclusively rely on findings from high-quality randomized controlled trials, disregarding other forms of evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: EBM categorically negates the intrinsic value of accumulated clinical experience, positioning empirical research findings as the sole determinant of clinical practice.

options.label: C
options.text: EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence.

options.label: D
options.text: EBM emphasizes a dependency on recommendations primarily made by pharmaceutical companies, given their investment in large-scale research.

questions.correct_answer: C. EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The core philosophy of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) is to integrate the clinician's expertise with the best available external evidence and patient values to make informed clinical decisions.
  • ➤ The core philosophy of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) is to integrate the clinician's expertise with the best available external evidence and patient values to make informed clinical decisions.

questions.text: While assessing children's nutritional status in a school, you come across a child with low height for age. What is this known as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Stunting

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Low height for age is referred to as stunting. Stunting is an indicator of chronic malnutrition, where the child's growth has been inhibited over a prolonged period.
  • • Note – Stunting is also known as Dwarfism
  • • Note
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Underweight : Low weight for age is known as underweight. It can indicate acute on chronic malnutrition.
  • • Option A. Underweight
  • • Low weight for age
  • • Option B. Wasting : Low weight for height is referred to as wasting. This indicates acute malnutrition, where there has been a significant recent weight loss. Wasting is also known as Emaciation .
  • • Option B. Wasting
  • • Low weight for height
  • • Emaciation
  • • Option C. Overweight : This indicates excess weight relative to height.
  • • Option C. Overweight

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low height for age is known as stunting and indicates chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is : ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • All listed infections—Chickenpox, Rubella, and CMV (Cytomegalovirus)—can potentially lead to teratogenic effects if a mother contracts them during pregnancy. Here's a brief explanation of how each can impact fetal development:
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Chickenpox : Infection in early pregnancy can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which includes skin scarring, limb abnormalities, and neurologic disorders.
  • • Option A. Chickenpox
  • • Option B. Rubella : Known for its teratogenic potential if contracted in the first trimester; can cause congenital rubella syndrome, leading to cataracts, deafness, heart defects, and neurological damage.
  • • Option B. Rubella
  • • Option C. CMV : The most common viral cause of congenital infections leading to developmental disabilities, including hearing loss, vision loss, and neurodevelopmental disorders.
  • • Option C. CMV
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is : TORCH infection
  • • T oxoplasmosis O ther (includes infections such as Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19, and Zika virus) R ubella C ytomegalovirus (CMV) H erpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
  • • T oxoplasmosis
  • • T
  • • O ther (includes infections such as Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19, and Zika virus)
  • • O
  • • R ubella
  • • R
  • • C ytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • • C
  • • H erpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
  • • H
  • • Note – Now, also includes – Treponema pallidum, HIV, Hep. B viruses
  • • Note

questions.text: An individual seeks to explore the correlation between smoking and lung cancer. To do so, they gather information on individuals diagnosed with lung cancer from government hospitals, along with data on the quantity of cigarette packets sold during the corresponding timeframe. What category of study does this represent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ecological

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ECOLOGICAL STUDY / CO-RELATIONAL STUDY
  • ➤ ECOLOGICAL STUDY / CO-RELATIONAL STUDY
  • ➤ Done at a point of time [E.g. in 2023] Used in Nutritional surveys, e.g. à Avg. fat intake = 20gm/day Can’t calculate strength of Association or Prevalence Based on secondary data [collected by someone else, studied by investigator]
  • ➤ Done at a point of time [E.g. in 2023]
  • ➤ Used in Nutritional surveys, e.g. à Avg. fat intake = 20gm/day
  • ➤ Can’t calculate strength of Association or Prevalence
  • ➤ Based on secondary data [collected by someone else, studied by investigator]

questions.text: Number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group per year is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GFR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The General Fertility Rate (GFR) is the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age (15-49 years) in a given year, making it a key measure of fertility in a population.
  • ➤ Note –
  • ➤ Note
  • ➤ TFR is also known as completed family size. To achieve NRR 1, couple protection rate should be more than 60%, which is already achieved Best contraceptive advisable is vasectomy (sterilization). As per NFHS 5, TFR goal was 2.1, India have already achieved the replacement level (TFR 2)
  • ➤ TFR is also known as completed family size.
  • ➤ To achieve NRR 1, couple protection rate should be more than 60%, which is already achieved
  • ➤ Best contraceptive advisable is vasectomy (sterilization).
  • ➤ As per NFHS 5, TFR goal was 2.1, India have already achieved the replacement level (TFR 2)

questions.text: A pregnant woman presenting at less than 34 weeks of gestation displays signs of mild to moderate anemia. Under the "Anemia Mukh Bharat" initiative, which therapeutic approach would be the most appropriate? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 3 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets, taken OD

options.label: B
options.text: IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets

options.label: C
options.text: 2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.correct_answer: B. IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anemia Mukt Bharat (2018)
  • ➤ Anemia Mukt Bharat (2018)
  • ➤ Aim: Reduce anemia by 3% per year
  • ➤ 6 x 6 x 6 strategy

questions.text: In the 18th century, the East India Company engaged in the illicit trade of a specific substance with China, which played a significant role in the historical trade dynamics. What was the substance that the company smuggled into China during this time? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Opium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In 18 th & 19 th centuaries, EIC (East India Company) used to purchase Tea against Silver. By opium export, EIC were able to save their Silver and purchased tea against Opium.
  • • Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cannabis: Marijuana, a psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.
  • • Option B. Cannabis: Marijuana, a
  • • Option C. Magic Mushrooms : Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.
  • • Option C. Magic Mushrooms
  • • Option D. Cocaine : Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.
  • • Option D. Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In 18 th century British East India company used to transport opium to China .

questions.text: Bilirubin is measured as mg/dl in which scale? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Continuous

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which is a continuous scale. Continuous quantitative data, where multiple values can exist between any two given values, is measured on a continuous or metric scale.
  • • Such as bilirubin levels of 4 mg/dl, 4.1 mg/dl, 4.25 mg/dl, 6 mg/dl, 7 mg/dl, 10 mg/dl, and 11.4 mg/dl, illustrate the continuous nature of the measurement, with numerous possible values between any two points.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ordinal: T his option is incorrect because ordinal scales represent ordered categories or ranks. This is discrete data
  • • Option
  • • A. Ordinal: T
  • • Option B. Nominal: This option is incorrect because nominal scales represent categories or names without any inherent order or quantitative value. This is discrete data
  • • Option
  • • B. Nominal:
  • • Option C. Discrete: This option is incorrect because discrete scales involve counting or whole numbers, whereas bilirubin measurements can have fractional or decimal values.
  • • Option
  • • C. Discrete:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which falls under the continuous scale, as it allows for numerous possible values between any two given points, reflecting the precise quantitative nature of the measurement.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). According to the World Health Organization's guidelines, which of the following treatment schedules is recommended? (AIIMS NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: 6 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 12 months

options.label: B
options.text: 7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months

options.label: C
options.text: 4 drugs for 4 months followed by 6 drugs for 10-12 months

options.label: D
options.text: 5 drugs for 6 months followed by 4 drugs for 12 months

questions.correct_answer: B. 7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ New Regimens for Treatment Drug Resistant TB (RNTCP 2017-18)

questions.text: Under MTP Act guidelines, to terminate Meningomyelocele fetus at 21 weeks POG (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Take mother's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

options.label: D
options.text: Take Husband's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

questions.correct_answer: C. Take mother's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under the MTP Act guidelines in India, terminating a fetus with meningomyelocele at 21 weeks of gestation requires the mother's consent and the opinion of two doctors.

questions.text: A pregnant woman residing in the same house as her niece, who has contracted Varicella, received a negative result in her test for serum antibodies against varicella. What implications can be drawn from this? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox

options.label: D
options.text: She is immune to chicken pox

questions.correct_answer: C. She is susceptible to chicken pox
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) She is susceptible to chicken pox

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative test result for serum antibodies against varicella indicates that the individual is susceptible to chicken pox, as there are no detectable antibodies suggesting past infection or vaccination.

questions.text: You are counseling a new mother about the importance of immunization for her newborn. She is particularly interested in understanding the BCG vaccine's benefits, as she has heard conflicting opinions from friends and family. Based on current evidence and guidelines, which of the following best describes the primary protective effects of the BCG vaccine in the context of tuberculosis (TB)? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CNS and disseminated TB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The BCG vaccine is primarily recommended for its effectiveness in preventing severe forms of tuberculosis, such as CNS and disseminated TB, in children.
  • ➤ The BCG vaccine is primarily recommended for its effectiveness in preventing severe forms of tuberculosis, such as CNS and disseminated TB, in children.

questions.text: To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, what level should the rate of couple protection exceed? (NEET PG 2018) (NRR: Net reproduction rate)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 60%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the rate of couple protection should exceed 60%. This level of contraceptive use helps in maintaining a stable population by ensuring that each woman, on average, has one daughter who survives to reproductive age.
